unnormalised: Another application I saw somewhere was related to stability analysis in engineering systems. Like, if you have a system described by differential equations, you can use eigenvalues of the system's matrix to determine if the system is stable or not. If all the eigenvalues have negative real parts, then the system is stable. If you want to model electrical circuits with capacitors (C= 10μF), inductors (L = 5mH), and resistors (R=10 Ohms), finding the eigenvalues helps you understand whether the circuit oscillates or decays.

unnormalised: And yes, absolutely AI. Eigenvalues and eigenvectors play a massive role in dimensionality reduction techniques like Principal Component Analysis (PCA). Imagine you're working with a dataset with tons of features, like a dataset of images of faces. Each image has 1000 features (1000 pixels), you can use PCA to find the "principal components," which are basically the eigenvectors corresponding to the largest eigenvalues of the covariance matrix of your data. You can use those few components to represent your data and cut the dimensions in ½. Then it's easier to build models (e.g., in image recognition).

You can use those few components to represent your data and cut the dimensions in one divided by two. Then it is easier to build models (e.g., in image recognition).
